Award.AwardTitle: Building the Capacity of STEM Teacher Preparation at Texas A&M University-Commerce

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Noyce project is building the capacity for talented undergraduate STEM majors to pursue teaching careers through two years of funding that will lead to to a later Phase I Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Track project. The project addresses state requirements for teacher certification as well as the research on how students learn STEM material in the classroom. STEM majors from Texas A&M-Commerce, including alternative certification programs, and 23 surrounding community colleges are identified and recruited in preparation for expansion of current STEM teacher production. In addition, a restructuring of the current student pathway and introduction of new instructional strategies strengthen the present STEM certification program.

The strategy to rebuild the infrastructure and capacity for STEM teacher preparation at the university includes merging advanced STEM content and teaching pedagogy in advanced STEM courses. Pilot summer internships, integrating research and education, are planned and implemented during the project period. The project fully utilizes university research groups to build a community network to mentor and support students while at the college or in the field. The uniqueness of this region adds to potential impact of the project. The region has 15 rural counties, with average family income well below the state average, as well as the large urban Dallas Metroplex area. Implementation of this capacity building model will be well-documented and can be replicated in other rural and urban settings, thereby expanding the impact beyond the targeted region.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project successfully completed the following three goals:

Restructuring the STEM teacher preapration program at Texas A&M University-Commerce was successfully completed through the close collaboration with the College of Education and the LeoTeach program. Pedagogical courses were redesigned to fit the needs of math and science teaching students. Two additional lab management courses were developed and offerred to future teachers to address the laboratory needs in secondary schools.

Through the connections built via previous and current REU, CCLI and S-STEM projects, the project team and other faculty provided seminars at community colleges to promote teaching internship opportunities. The increased awareness strengthened the partnerships with community colleges. With the majority of higher education students going to community colleges, the partnerships with rural and urban community colleges would provide opporties for these students to pursue STEM teaching crdentials.

The project team was aware of the importance of preparing STEM teaching majors with a full knowledge of the impact of poverty, isolation, and language and other issues in high-needs schools. The partnership with high-needs districts were redefined to allowed both pedagogical and content faculty to visit teaching students for enhancing mentoring impact and to provide support addressing issues. The collaboration had also allowed student teachers to have increased opportunities to use their content and management training in the classsroom setting.
